p.s: I heard about your plans of going to Germany, which to my mind is a great idea.
You asked me about Berlin and I found the perfect newspaper article.
It's called Berlin spricht Englisch, written by Marina Kormbaki and was published in the Hannoversche Allgemeine Zeitung on the 15th July 2016.
As you can tell it is a German text so I will sum up all the information you need.
the headline already gives you an answer, it says Berlin speaks English.
Of course that isn't everything Marina Kormbaki has a lot of examples and evidence.
First of all there are hundreds of thousand english speakingEnglish-speaking travelers and a lot of them stay.
This leads to similarityssimilarities with cityscities like London, Brooklyn and Sydney.
Kormbaki States that sometimes you don't hear a single germanGerman word while walking through parts of Berlin, like Neuk√∂lln and Kreuzberg.
But it is not necessarily English as the arabicArabic language is pretty common as well.
Nevertheless you can go wherever you want there will always be someone that speaks englishEnglish.
Especially the author points out the food that is mainly englishEnglish.
besides Berlin being a city where you can easily communicate with others, there are more advantages.
First of all Berlin has relatively low rents, when compared to other big cities and an overall cheap livelife.
So you could get a job, that you couldn't get back in Camden, such as Orta Baumgarten who is Irish and now owns a book shop she couldn't afford.
Furthermore Kormbaki mentions another man called David Walker, who used to live in England.
He works in a company with 21 different nations, so Berlin is also a city where you can meet new cultures.
all in all Berlin is a affordable city to lifelive in, where you can communicate with almost everybody everywhere and gives room to expand your horizon.
